Ask HN: (How) can data help cities?
text:
Last week there was a post about the dilemmas in the general theory of planning [https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=32943474] (from 1973) and the difficulties/impossibilities of optimizing wicked problems, with urban planning named specifically as such a wicked problem.

Even so, there are lots of companies working in the space of ‘urban innovation’, and many local governments are aiming to become ‘data driven smart cities’. It seems to me that most of the focus in this space now is on creating technical platforms (‘digital twins’) and collecting relatively large amounts data while there is less focus on any future use of that data.

I’m curious what you think about the potential use of (large amounts of) data for improving cities. Can the use of data improve life in city? If so, who can/should make use of it: policy makers (urban planning), or only businesses or citizens (optimizing own behaviour). Should choosing (non-wicked) goals for optimization be a part of the democratic process?

Show HN: Impulse – Impossible Dev Tools for React and Tailwind
text:
Writing HTML sucks.

I've been making websites and web apps for almost 10 years. As a developer, I've never liked it.

React and Tailwind made it an infinitely better experience for me, but something was still missing. Switching between the code and the browser all the time felt wrong. At the same time, I felt lost with No-code editors because they are made for designers not developers.

I've written about it extensively here: https://rogovoy.me/blog/writing-html-sucks

Impulse is my experiment to bridge that gap and make a "design" tool that works directly with my code.

With Impulse, I've come to love web design (again?).
